items.title: Why four transformations?
items.content:
ROOT: Context windows are finite
-> State must persist externally (Transform 1)
-> Sessions must be fresh (Transform 2)
-> Systems must be designed, not prompted (Transform 3)
-> Specialists must replace generalists (Transform 4)

items.title: What these transformations validate
items.content:
INV-1: Context is constraint (finite)
INV-2: External state over internal memory
INV-3: Fresh context beats extended sessions
INV-4: Verification as trust boundary
INV-5: Parallelization over single-agent
These are physics, not preferences.

items.title: Software engineering parallels
items.content:
Transform 1: Stateful -> Stateless (HTTP)
Transform 2: Monolith -> Worker queues
Transform 3: Scripting -> System design
Transform 4: Monolith -> Microservices
The same patterns, different substrate.

items.title: Why you cannot skip levels
items.content:
Week 1: "Why can't I just start with swarms?"
Week 4: "My swarm is chaos - no shared state"
Week 8: "Oh. I needed filesystem state first."
Month 3: "Each transformation solves ONE problem"
The progression exists because each level reveals the next wall.

items.title: Where are you on the ladder?
items.content:
Level 0: Manual context, re-explaining patterns
Level 1: Files persist but sessions degrade
Level 2: Fresh loops but no parallelization
Level 3-4: Agent thinking but generic workers
Level 5-6: Specialized swarm, true scale
Identify your current pain to find your next transformation.

items.title: What if you skipped Transform 1?
items.content:
Without filesystem state, Ralph loops have no memory.
Without Ralph, agent systems have no iteration.
Without agent thinking, swarms have no coordination.
Each transformation is a prerequisite.

items.title: Matt Pocock's Ralph journey
items.content:
Started with manual prompting. Hit context rot at 80K tokens. Moved to Ralph loops with prd.json. Now runs overnight development on Total TypeScript.

"The learning compounds. By story 10, Ralph knew our patterns."

items.title: Complexity vs. capability
items.content:
Transform 1: Low overhead, high compound value
Transform 2: Setup cost, unlocks overnight work
Transform 3: Mindset shift, enables scaling
Transform 4: High coordination cost, true parallelism
Each transformation adds complexity. Only transform when the pain exceeds the cost.

items.title: If you transform prematurely
items.content:
IF: You adopt swarms before hitting generalist limits
THEN: Coordination overhead exceeds benefits
THEN: You blame the pattern, not the timing
THEN: You regress to manual approaches
FINALLY: You miss the actual scaling opportunity
Wait for the pain before applying the cure.

items.title: The "Aha" moment for each transformation
items.content:
Transform 1: "I've explained this pattern to Claude 5 times this week"
Transform 2: "Claude's quality dropped after hour 2 - again"
Transform 3: "I spent more time on this prompt than the feature"
Transform 4: "The frontend is great but the API is broken"
The pain tells you when to transform.
